NBA 2K24 builds on the solid foundation of other nba 2k games, offering familiar gameplay with some improvements in mechanics and visuals. The new shooting mechanics take a little getting used to, but once mastered, they add depth and precision to the experience.

I played mostly in career mode, which continues to be engaging and rewarding. While my PC handles most games easily, 2K24 runs poorly on higher settings, so playing on low is necessary ‚Äî not ideal, but manageable. Overall, the experience feels very similar to 2K22, and longtime fans will feel right at home.

Although the online servers are scheduled to close eventually, the single-player content alone makes it worth playing for NBA enthusiasts.

I‚Äôm really disappointed with this game because it feels like nothing more than a rebranded version of the previous NBA 2K title. The lack of innovation is frustrating‚Äîespecially considering the developers had an entire year to make meaningful improvements. Aside from minor HUD changes, NBA 2K24 feels virtually identical to NBA 2K23. It comes across as lazy and uninspired, and longtime fans deserve better.

NBA 2K24 continues the franchise's tradition of being the go-to basketball simulator, offering a slick mix of gameplay improvements, visual fidelity, and game modes that will keep basketball fans coming back for more. While the game makes significant strides in some areas, it‚Äôs also clear that there‚Äôs still a few areas that could use some refinement.

The core gameplay in NBA 2K24 feels as polished as ever. The ball physics are responsive, the player movements are fluid, and the animations continue to impress. Whether you're sinking a clutch 3-pointer or fighting for a tough rebound in the paint, the on-court action feels realistic, with the new "Pro Play" feature pushing the boundaries of player movement and animation.

However, as with many yearly installments, the gameplay feels iterative rather than revolutionary. While there are noticeable improvements, like enhanced shooting mechanics and better off-ball movement, it‚Äôs still fundamentally similar to NBA 2K23 and previous titles in the series. For fans of the franchise, this consistency is a plus, but newcomers might feel like there‚Äôs not enough of a "wow" factor to justify an immediate purchase.

The MyCareer mode continues to be the centerpiece of NBA 2K24, and it‚Äôs clear that 2K is putting serious effort into refining this experience. The narrative in MyCareer feels more polished and engaging than ever, with voice acting and storylines that push you deeper into the world of professional basketball. You‚Äôll navigate off-the-court drama, build your brand, and make decisions that affect your path to NBA greatness.

There‚Äôs also a more expansive focus on team chemistry and your role within your chosen franchise, adding a bit more realism to how you integrate with other players on the roster. The grind is still present, but now there are a few more rewarding mechanics to make progression feel a bit more natural.

NBA 2K24 brings back the expansive "City" mode, where players can freely explore, interact with others, and participate in various side activities and games. While the environment looks great and the social aspect of this mode is fun, it still suffers from some performance issues and occasional lag, especially in crowded areas. Load times are long, and the online connection can be spotty ‚Äî something that detracts from the overall experience, particularly for those who want a seamless multiplayer experience.

That said, the online play itself is as enjoyable as ever, with modes like Rec and Pro-Am providing intense, competitive action. For those who prefer casual play, the various park and streetball modes still offer fun alternatives.

Graphically, NBA 2K24 continues to impress with next-gen visuals. The player models are incredibly lifelike, the arenas are rich in detail, and the lighting and crowd animations make every game feel alive. The broadcast-style presentation is top-notch, adding to the overall immersion. It‚Äôs clear that NBA 2K24 is pushing the limits of current-gen hardware.

While the core gameplay is solid, NBA 2K24 still grapples with its monetization strategies. The game continues to push microtransactions through its in-game currency, VC, and the progression systems tied to it. Unlocking cosmetics, gear, and boosting your MyCareer player‚Äôs attributes often feels like a grind unless you‚Äôre willing to spend extra money. This continues to be a sore spot for the community, especially considering how many gameplay aspects are tied to VC.

NBA 2K24 is a fantastic basketball experience that‚Äôs fun for both hardcore fans and casual players, offering an immersive, visually stunning, and mostly enjoyable package. However, the game still suffers from issues like long load times, inconsistent online play, and a frustrating reliance on microtransactions. The series has certainly evolved, but it‚Äôs clear that there‚Äôs still room for improvement in delivering a more seamless and balanced experience.

A solid entry that hits the mark in many areas but still leaves room for improvement, especially in online play and monetization.

A Slam Dunk for Fans, but Still Room for Growth

Still pretty sad that this was still a Last Gen only port to PC but whatever. 2K24 on PC feels like it's held together by a shoestring, with many textures and shaders struggling to form. I primarily used 2K24 for MyPlayer content: MyCareer and Park, so I can't speak on MyTeam or MyLeague. MyCareer offline is everything you can expect to find in any other 2K. Park/Pro-Am/REC gameplay feels fun, but you are held at the mercy of modders, cheaters, and hackers who will green full-court shots or dunk from the half-court line. If you buy this on sale solely for offline aspects, there's a lot you can do, especially with mods. Buying this for the online aspects is a waste of time and money unless you hate your life.

Casual Gamer got this game for about 10$ for career mode but like many people say, CAREER MODE IS STRAIGHTLY GARBAGEEEEEEEEEE ! Please don't spend any money for this dogshit game especially CAREER MODE if you want to maintain your sanity. Those gonna be my review after 100 hours playing this mode: 
- No Story, very confused instructions to start quest if you are new player. 
- You start 60 overall playing against superstar like Steph, Bron, .... Good luck defending those. You can only hope to contribute by pass to your AI or try to get open layup.

Below is a subjective review for 2k24 however I can sum it up for steam players in just a few words. Apparently they dont feel like PC is next gen since this game isnt next gen. Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ (2/5)

Pros:

Next-Gen Graphics: NBA 2K24 takes graphics to a new level, with improved player models, enhanced lighting, and ultra-realistic court details. Everything from player sweat to jersey movement is meticulously rendered, providing a visually stunning experience. The arena atmosphere has been improved as well, making games feel more authentic and intense.

ProPLAY Animation System: One of the headline features, ProPLAY captures real NBA footage and translates it directly into the game, making player movements more lifelike than ever. Dribbling, shooting, and defensive mechanics feel noticeably smoother and more realistic, adding depth to gameplay for both veterans and newcomers.

Mamba Moments: This new mode is a heartfelt tribute to Kobe Bryant, letting players re-live iconic moments from his legendary career. It‚Äôs an exciting addition that pays respect to one of the game‚Äôs greats, complete with challenges that capture Kobe‚Äôs unique playstyle and legacy.

MyTeam with Crossplay: NBA 2K24 now offers crossplay for MyTeam, allowing PlayStation and Xbox players to compete with each other. The card-collecting mode has also been simplified, and several fan-favorite features, like the return of MT, make MyTeam more accessible for players who don‚Äôt want to spend on microtransactions.

MyCareer with Expanded City & New Storyline: The City has been expanded with more interactive elements, and the MyCareer storyline offers a fresh, cinematic journey that dives into the challenges of being a rising NBA star. The new RPG-like decision-making elements let players shape their journey more meaningfully.

Cons:

Heavily Monetized Microtransactions: Unfortunately, NBA 2K24‚Äôs reliance on microtransactions is as strong as ever. VC is still required for nearly every aspect of progression in MyCareer and MyTeam. Grinding VC without spending real money remains extremely slow, and it can feel pay-to-win, especially in online modes.

Limited Innovation Beyond Visuals: While the game shines in presentation, the core gameplay feels only slightly refined from NBA 2K23. Some long-standing issues with defense and shot timing remain, and veterans might find the gameplay too similar, with few substantial changes in mechanics.

MyCareer‚Äôs Grind Remains: Although the storyline is fresh, the grind for badges, attributes, and VC continues. Unless you‚Äôre willing to put in serious time or invest in VC, character progression can feel frustratingly slow, impacting the enjoyment of MyCareer‚Äôs more competitive aspects.

Server Instability and Latency: Even with crossplay, server issues continue to be a drawback. Players report latency and occasional disconnects in online modes, which can be disruptive in competitive play and negatively affect the experience.

AI Inconsistencies: The AI, while improved, still has moments of odd decision-making, especially in team-based modes. Whether it's teammates making strange choices on defense or opponents seeming unusually overpowered, the AI could use some fine-tuning.

Verdict: NBA 2K24 is a visually impressive installment with new features like ProPLAY and Mamba Moments that add depth and excitement. However, its heavy reliance on microtransactions and lack of major gameplay innovations leave it feeling a bit stagnant. Longtime fans of the series might enjoy the nostalgia and Kobe Bryant tributes, but new players or those wary of microtransactions may find the experience frustrating. It‚Äôs a solid game, but one that falls short of pushing the series forward.

From the moment the game booted up, NBA 2K24 Kobe Bryant Edition made it clear this wasn't just a tribute but a true homage to Kobe's legacy. As a first-time player diving into this edition, I was immediately struck by the level of realism in both graphics and gameplay mechanics. The opening scenes that highlight Kobe‚Äôs legendary career moments set the tone with a mix of nostalgia and awe. Once on the court, the improvements in player movements, dribbling, and shooting mechanics were apparent, especially the attention to Kobe‚Äôs signature moves and style. Executing his fadeaway or spin move felt so satisfying; it‚Äôs as if the game captured the essence of his playstyle.

The MyCareer mode brings an added layer of depth, particularly for those who idolize Kobe. From designing your own player to choosing a playstyle, each choice echoes Kobe's tenacity and ambition. As I progressed, the new ProPLAY technology shone through, with smoother animations and more lifelike player interactions that brought the entire court to life. The integration of Kobe-themed content, like his jerseys, challenges, and special rewards, added an extra motivation to keep playing and aim higher‚Äîmirroring the Mamba Mentality. Even the atmosphere in the arenas felt amplified, with crowd reactions and commentary that paid subtle nods to Kobe‚Äôs influence on the game and the league as a whole.

Overall, the NBA 2K24 Kobe Bryant Edition doesn‚Äôt just provide a typical sports game experience. It offers a heartfelt tribute to Kobe, reminding fans why he was such an icon. For anyone stepping into his shoes for the first time, the game delivers on every level, bridging past and present in a way only NBA 2K can achieve.

In all honesty, the game isn't bad. Would it make the game better if this was next-gen? Probably. Would people play the game more if there weren't sweaty 99 overalls every single time you boot up the game? Yes. However, 2K doesn't make it impossible to grind MyCareer, I'm an 85 overall with no money spent so far. The hours I've played hasn't been all spent on MyCareer, its been mostly spent AFK because I just leave my computer on at night sometimes. Sure this 2K isn't all that great, but its definitely not the worst. The delay in Park and Rec doesn't make the game unplayable, it just takes adjusting. Game's physics are pretty realistic and offer consistent results, for the most part. I wouldn't buy the game at full price, and I would just wait for 2K25 at this point. Most of these reviews are just a bunch of complainers because they aren't good at the game.
more on bug like i didnt connect mycareer

2k is on downhill since like 2k18... Compared to the 2k23 it is a disappointing "update"... The movements improved a lot, the game looks fantastic, but no MyCarrier story at all, if you start a 3 pointer you will miss most of your shots, doesn't matter if you stay alone without somebody guarding you... All my games is about raging and alt+F4-ing, when in the 2k23 was more enjoyment and has more motivation even if you loose. Unfortunately 2k forgot all those who played them game for MyCarrier mode, and they just focused on your money as every single time the game kinda force you to buy more VC's. It's now just a pay to win game with no fun for the "single players"... They still not fixed the bug where you are on the bench and want to skip the time. The time is just slowly goes slower and slower for almost a minute before you can skip it. Fortunately Alt+Tab can help that. Also still need to wait a lot on timeouts before you can skip. The "dance" moves are still looks like a bunch of idiots just jumping around on the court. I feel 2k is out of passion for this game... I'm so disappointed and sad as I was always enjoyed to play NBA games even on PS, but definitely not gonna buy the next one (or any of the future releases) until they get back on track... :(

Calling this a tribute to Kobe might be one of the biggest insults Take-Two has ever dished out. The NBA games used to be incredible with amazing play style that kept people wanting to play. This new format for NBA games is a hideous, trashy version of something that was so beautiful. The central hub for your created player is hard to look at with the focus on sponsorships so shamelessly plugged you can't even enjoy PvP. The created player format is a catastrophe with the only way to somewhat level up (aside from grinding 1,000 NBA games or playing PvP against people that will dominate you without you scoring a single bucket) is to buy their "Virtual Currency." Take-Two isn't even trying to hide the scummy system with the VC credits being slammed down your throat at every turn. Take-Two can go fuck themselves if they think this is the direction people want gaming to go. Let's not forget you get the pleasure of starting over a little over a year after the game comes out because they shut the servers down and, here's the kicker, you cannot do an offline mode for your created player. So the money or time you wasted on this shit game goes right out the door. Save you time, save your money, and fuck Take-Two.

NBA 2K24 for PC plays a pretty good game of basketball if you are playing offline. The game is overall much smoother and more fluid as far as gameplay. Players run the court with a sense of purpose as they will position and reposition themselves to make plays naturally which is a welcome change. With that being said AI seems vastly improved. But overall the game is pretty much very similar to last year's installment.

The stadium atmosphere is electric, and big plays seem to garner a huge reaction from the crowd this year. Close games feel realistic as playoff games sound and look like high intensity playoff games. Crowd noise is robust and gives you a true sense of a real NBA game atmosphere. One thing I feel is off is the booing... especially for road teams. Would like to see crowds more rambunctious especially with rivalry games.

Presentation is top notch per usual. The various broadcast combinations available give the game fresh life as Kevin Harlan's voice has worn on my ears over the years. I would love to have a choice on the team select screen to chose our broadcast style. For example we could choose local or national tv broadcast presentation. Each having their own unique feel, style & mode specific broadcasters.

 
As far as mods for this game... it has been a mixed bag of good and bad, but mostly bad. Mods this year are basically hit or miss. The issues arise whenever I try and mod this game. 2K24 seems to glitch out bad when adding certain mods this year, especially Looyh's Hook which allows for more complex modding, seems to be broken for 2K24. There is a work around to fix this but finding that fix online can be a pain. Mod sites tend to post mods but very few if any clear instructions on how to install these mods. So a lot of people are turned off from even trying to mod 2K. A lot of content creators in the NBA2K PC community are trash and don't do a good job of explaining. Or either they make 20+ minute videos that ultimately just babble and don't help. Seems like support for most mods we have grown to love have disappeared this year as most modders have abandoned 2K on PC for refusing to give us the "next-gen" version we desired in previous years. Though we will see "next-gen" on PC with 2K25 the jury is still out on how "mod-friendly" this game will be. Unfortunately the NBA2K PC community has died off. People like "The Goods" and "Shady Mike" do their best to keep the community alive but truth is there aren't enough PC gamers interested in 2K anymore to have a strong online presence. Thus why I believed 2K was hesitant to release next-gen on PC. Was just not enough people overall playing NBA2K on PC to be profitable... thus the modding community suffers.

MyCareer is an extremely frustrating experience unless you are willing to pay for your character to be maxed out and that could cost well over $150 in real money to purchase "Virtual Currency" to level up your player. Totally not worth the effort and I suggest you bypass this mode at all cost. A fun alternative is Mamba Moments where you play significant historic games of the late, great Kobe Bryant. Free to play and loads of fun.

My verdict... if you can find this game cheap then I guess it's worth a buy, but I would never pay full price for this game in it's current state. If you have 2K23 then I'd say keep it and just mod it up. There seems to be  much more mod choices for 2K23 than 2K24. If you plan to mod this game... do your research to even see if it's worth it.
If you like torturing yourself and you like basketball, this game is for you!!! Its so fun and definitely not pay to win.

This game is a complete miserable failure!

Everything about it is wrong. The last NBA 2K game that I've played was 2K14. How on earth did this franchise reach such a low standard? MyCareer is a soulless joke. If 10 years ago you would start in college and play some games in order to be drafted according to your performance and interviews with the scouts from different teams, here you just select the desired NBA team and there you go; you're a starter with a 60 rating.

I wouldn't mind the grinding because in the older titles you would also need one full season to be a decent player and increase the rating. The difference is that this time they push the micro transactions in a crazy way by offering the most artificial grinding that I've ever encountered. In the older titles you would still make some shots, even 3 pointers, while here it's almost impossible. The only way that I've found to make it more effective is to lower the difficulty while only doing pick'n'rolls. The game literally makes your experience in MyCareer unbearable and utterly not enjoyable in order to push you to buy credits and increase your player's rating.

The open world (neighborhood or whatever it's called) is something that I don't enjoy at all. Why can't I use the standard menu to buy shoes instead of having to ride some stupid goofy hoverboard to the store? Also, why do I have to spent credits on shoes? In the older titles you could wear whatever shoe you wanted. What is more, you could even design your own shoe after getting endorsed by some manufacturer. Probably here you can as well, but I couldn't care less as I'm not going to attempt to progress further.

Just don't buy it.

Buy this if you're only want to enjoy the game as a single-player experience or the price is drop on sale.

The Reasons:
1. Dozens of cheaters in the online multiplayer mode in MyCareer. I met an 60s OVR player online and always do 3s and always green beans. Glad I wasn't on the opposite team. But you're unfortunate to be their opponent team.

2. You're a F2P = You had to embrace the Imbalance online gameplay experience. Most of the players are cheaters or already 99 OVR (cuz reason number 1 and 4 ) and I don't think 2K want to handle some "pity" issues like this right now or in the future.

3. No story (again) in MyCareer mode. No high school and college match. Just straight into your first NBA match and play basketball till you're bored to death. No side activities in your schedule whatsoever. Dull to infinity and beyond.

4. And the final reason, you just need to spend your money for VC, and everything will be easy.

BUT, if you're looking for a basketball simulation game... I still not recommended this, lol.
Cuz the NBA 2K25 already release so, just buy the latest version if you can afford it or never play NBA 2K before. No need to think twice if the price drop on sale (And it definitely will drop). NBA 2K25 is the same port as the next-gen console version. So, the MyCareer mode will have some stories (high-school and college game and some cutscenes), the micro-transaction still unhealthy, still a pay to win game. But hey, it's still much better version than this one. A bit.

[h1] Schqrk's Review: NBA 2K24 - The Court Awaits [/h1]

[h2] Review Date: [/h2]
August 14, 2024

[h2] Overall Rating: [/h2]
7/10 ‚≠ê

[h2] Completion: [/h2]
100%

[hr][/hr]

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

[i]NBA 2K24[/i], developed by Visual Concepts, continues the long-standing tradition of delivering a highly realistic basketball simulation experience. Building on its predecessors, the game introduces new features, refined mechanics, and updated rosters to bring the excitement of the NBA to players' screens.

[h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]

[‚úîÔ∏è] üèÄ Realistic Player Models: [i]NBA 2K24[/i] showcases impressive player likenesses and accurate team uniforms. The game‚Äôs attention to detail in player models and animations enhances the authenticity of the basketball experience.

[‚úîÔ∏è] üèüÔ∏è Dynamic Arenas: The game features well-crafted arenas with realistic crowd animations and dynamic lighting effects. Each venue captures the atmosphere of an actual NBA game, contributing to the immersive experience.

[h2] Gameplay and Mechanics [/h2]

[‚úîÔ∏è] üèÄ Improved Gameplay Mechanics: [i]NBA 2K24[/i] introduces refined gameplay mechanics, including enhanced shooting controls and more responsive dribbling. These improvements aim to create a more fluid and realistic on-court experience.

[‚úîÔ∏è] üìà MyCareer Mode: The MyCareer mode offers an engaging single-player experience where players can build their NBA career from the ground up. New features and storylines provide depth and replayability to the mode.

[h2] Story and Narrative [/h2]

[‚úîÔ∏è] üìñ Engaging Storylines: [i]NBA 2K24[/i] continues to build on the narrative elements of MyCareer, offering players an opportunity to experience the rise of their created player through a series of engaging storylines and career milestones.

[h2] Audio and Sound Design [/h2]

[‚úîÔ∏è] üéµ Dynamic Soundtrack: The game features a diverse soundtrack with tracks from various genres, enhancing the overall gaming experience. The music selection adds energy and excitement to the gameplay.

[‚úîÔ∏è] üîä Realistic Court Sounds: The audio design includes realistic court sounds such as ball dribbles, sneaker squeaks, and crowd reactions, contributing to the immersive atmosphere of the game.

[h2] Content and Replayability [/h2]

[‚úîÔ∏è] üîÑ Multiple Game Modes: [i]NBA 2K24[/i] offers a variety of game modes, including MyTeam, MyCareer, and online multiplayer. The diverse modes provide plenty of content and opportunities for replayability.

[‚úîÔ∏è] üèÜ Seasonal Updates: The game includes seasonal updates and events that keep the content fresh and engaging throughout the year, offering new challenges and rewards for players.

[h2] Pros and Highlights [/h2]

[‚úîÔ∏è] üåü Realistic Presentation: The game excels in delivering a realistic basketball simulation with accurate player models, dynamic arenas, and immersive audio.

[‚úîÔ∏è] üéÆ Enhanced Gameplay Mechanics: The improvements in shooting controls and dribbling contribute to a more fluid and enjoyable on-court experience.

[h2] Cons and Drawbacks [/h2]

[‚ùå] üí∏ Microtransactions: The presence of microtransactions in various game modes, particularly MyTeam, can be a drawback for players who prefer a more straightforward experience without additional costs.

[‚ùå] üîÑ Limited Innovation: While the game refines existing mechanics, some players may find that [i]NBA 2K24[/i] does not introduce significant new features compared to its predecessors.

[h2] Additional Comments [/h2]

[i]NBA 2K24[/i] continues to build on the strengths of the series with realistic graphics, improved gameplay mechanics, and engaging content. While it maintains the high standards of the franchise, the presence of microtransactions and a lack of major innovations may impact its appeal to some players.

[h2] Why 7/10? [/h2]

‚≠ê [i]NBA 2K24[/i] earns a 7/10 for its realistic presentation and refined gameplay mechanics. Although it offers an enjoyable basketball experience, the presence of microtransactions and limited innovation may affect its overall value for some players.

Let me start by saying this: PLEASE DO NOT BUY NBA 2K GAMES! 

The amount of greed and laziness is apparently endless in the world of 2k. Every year they hype up their games: new animations, groundbreaking player movement, never before seen realism. They say their product is the closest thing to real basketball in the virtual space. Technically, they're right: sadly 2k has no competitors making Nba games, and this is the biggest shame in sports games' existence!
I put countless hours into playing 2k21, but you know, they kill online servers, and I craved a bit of mycareer so I bought this game during the 2024 summer sale. It took me just a few hours to realise, this is the SAME GAME as 2k21 but somehow even worse! 
I mean it is just so irritating that people keep buying these games and 2k has no incentive whatsoever to make a remotely enjoyable product because the money is still pouring in even with the tiniest effort. This beautiful game has the same exact animations, same cutscenes, same line by commentators, exact same gamemodes without any improvement, it is a pure copy-paste game and I'm comparing it to 2k21, not even last year's game!! This is a mere skin update: they reworked the menus a little bit, created an awful neighbourhood (which is completely dead by now) and that's it! A mere roster update and the added mambe moments which I don't bother playing with anyway. And I just can't express how painful it was to enjoy the gameplay: how do you make the core of the game, the actual basketball even worse? It is outrageous how little effort they put into developing this crap. The gamemode that everyone waits for, the main attraction, MyCareer, it is simply a cheap, greedy cash grab, nothing more! You are thrown into the Nba as a 60 Overall. 60! You know how low that is? And this 60 overall player is way worse than let's say a MyLeague 60 overall guy! Way off, not exaggereating! Side note: you are supposed to be a first round pick, still, your player completely sucks. So, let's ignore the fact that your player has not been given any background story, no high school or college gameplay, nothing. (By the way, in 2k21 we had a decent story and you could actually enjoy the gameplay at the college level.) Do you know why we have to live with the abscence of any mycareer story? Because if you were to have that time to work through your way into the nba, you could actually upgrade your build, get to know the game a little bit, etc. No, instead you are the most average player ever who can't make a wide open layup on pro difficulty! Why? To make you empty your wallet right away to buy a load of vc and upgrade your build in order to have a somewhat enjoyable experience! You may think I'm using over the top words to describe this, but this attitude is disgusting, and I haven't even talked about how crazy expensive the upgrades have become, compared to recent games! You may have to spend 100-200 euros plus (or even more, especially if you want to max out more than one build) over the original price of the game! This is revolting, nothing less!
Oh and the gameplay? I have never wanted to delete a game more times before! The actual basketball is barely enjoyable sometimes! Ai defenders have a 60-70% contest just by being next to me, while my perfect defense is only enough for, let's say a 20% contest. Ai players' IQ is below comprehension also, both on offense and defense. 9 times out of 10 they don't bother playing help defence and it's sooo annyoing! Also, the schemes I learned in 2k21 are still working, because this is the exact same game!!

All in all, I think players have to stop buying these games, because if not, nothing is going to change and 2k36 will still be the same game that we had 20 years prior. This company has become so money-hunting that no user feedback is being considered! It is also outrageous how console players get preferential treatment over the pc version, bc those next gen 2ks are a different category compared to this mess. 
I am almost glad that the support cycle is ending and shortly they're taking down this game from the store, because I don't wish to my worst enemy to play Nba 2k24!

This review aims to MyCareer and MyTeam modes. Terrible pay to win experience. You start off in career mode with a 60 OVR player, no storyline like the previous games, and you're expected to play more than you want to have a decent player, or pay to progress faster and reach max overall if you spend too much money. And for what, for a game that the "sim to next appearance" option does not work and you have to wait until you get subbed in again (happens to me). No fair matchmaking of course, since they want you to be stepped upon until you pay for VC and create a playable character. Same thing in MyTeam. No effort from 2K to create a fair matchmaking system (70 vs 90 overall for instance) for the reason stated above. You should gamble on player packs (like EA FC24 UT) if you want to get the best players. Imo virtual basketball is destroyed since NBA 2K17 and won't be revived until some big company creates its own virtual basketball game, which means competition. So if you're after MyCareer or MyTeam don't bother buying any NBA 2K game if you don't want to spend big money. UNLESS you want to play some good ol' single player mode, which is constantly improving in terms of graphics, animations and stuff. Haven't played too much tho.

i never played many sports games as a kid nor cared about sports until fairly recently, but after spending a lot of time with mlb the show and gaining newfound appreciation for baseball because of it i decided to try out the games for other sports and i have to say this is not it. first off 150gb... really? fifa is less than 50 and has more teams, stadiums, and players and other games that are 150gb like cod have so much more to do (and look and run significantly better). second this game loves to waste your time. in the 7~ hours i played in my career my guy went from being a 60 overall to a 63 while in fifa i gained 5 overall in half the time. third this game loves to waste your money, if you want to skip the tedious grinding in my career you can just buy points to make your guy better which just feels bad in a full price game, especially if you want to play online with your guy. similarly, if you don't spend money on my team you just cannot compete with those who have. i did not spend a dime on the show besides the entry fee and was able to get a 99 overall diamond dynasty team without too much trouble. the gameplay is fine but nothing to write home about. the only good thing about this game is that i can play it on pc which beats the show and nhl. maybe pick it up if its on sale and you don't already have another 2k but i would not spend more than $10 on this and i have no plans of buying another years one unless significant changes are made

After almost 60 hours of gameplay in My Career player mode I couldn't take it anymore. I held it until I couldn't, but there is no other word to describe this game but s**t. I've known 2k since the 2k14 version and have played several of their releases. And I certainly only enjoy playing career mode, but it's impossible here. Your player grows at a snail's pace, and even if you've put in money to increase your skills quickly, it doesn't help at all. I'm not new to playing sports games, I'm not new to 2k either. By the time you want to reach an average of 80, most of the players you know today are already in retirement. Not to mention that your player and not just him, but your whole team sucks. I thought playing at the higher settings I could get my team to do what they are supposed to do, not be so stupid, but it's crazy. It doesn't matter if you go to Dallas, Golden, Lakers, you can play with all the best players on your team, that easily teams from mid-table down can beat you in the game and by a landslide. The rival teams, the machine you're competing with, take the most impossible shots, you'll s**t in your seat. It doesn't matter if they are guarded at 100%. Embid has the speed of a skinny small forward. All the big guys on the teams that the machine controls, make three pointers like they were Curry, and you go and look at their 3s stats and they average 55 or less. All my matches I finish with an A score, but it makes no sense at all when you just watch your team be so stupid. It's super annoying. I understand that they have to add difficulty to the game, but let's see, unless you're a gaming addict, you're not going to stomach this kind of stuff. There are a lot of weird moves too. My last player was a 7'1" center and even then, he couldn't pass and get out of the way of a 6'1" player. It's like they tie up your player and he can't get off. Where in the h** does that make sense? Not to mention the rebounding, no.... This game is a 2/5 for me. The fact that there is no Draft and you pick your own team to play for seems horrible to me as well.

The gameplay mechanics have been refined, offering smoother and more responsive controls, which enhance the overall gaming experience. The AI has also seen significant improvements, providing a more challenging and realistic opponent.

One of the highlights of NBA 2K24 is its stunning graphics and attention to detail. The player models, arenas, and animations are incredibly lifelike, making you feel like you‚Äôre part of the action. The game also introduces new modes and updates to existing ones, ensuring there‚Äôs always something fresh to explore.

Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned player or new to the series, NBA 2K24 offers a comprehensive and immersive basketball experience that is hard to beat. It‚Äôs a game that will keep you engaged for hours with its depth and realism.

I generally only get newer sports games in a franchise once every few years, as more often then not, they don't change too much each year. 2K games change even less and I hadn't put much serious time into any of them since NBA 2K16 which I played on both PC and console.

I got NBA 2k24 on sale as I do all NBA 2K games because to be honest, they really aren't worth their AAA pricetage considering the fact you need to pour more money into them to be competitive. NBA2K's online play is not friendly for newcomers and has always been a bit grindy with microtransactions to speed up the process to get anywhere, but it [i]was[/i] doable. 
Not the case with 2K24. Unless you are playing offline alone and don't mind a slow and torturous grind just to get your player up to "average", you will need to spend. They have slowed progression down to a crawl sucking all the fun out of the game for those who don't. You will need to spend and spend and spend to do anything and get anywhere.


It has become nothing more than what should be a F2P game with microtransactions, except it comes with a premium AAA pricetag which is sickening when you learn just how much they make on each NBA 2K game. The graphics and gameplay have barely changed in 8 years and will probably be surpassed on PC by the mobile versions soon enough. 
It's yet another outdated lazy stripped down POS cashgrab on PC which is only worth getting at a massive discount if you are playing one on one with your friends. Even then, the servers will be closed soon enough which is what forces people to essentially buy the same game again each year.  

This is the worse 2K game I have played and they will keep doing this as long as Take-Two have a monopoly on the NBA license. We really need another company to come in and give them some competition even if it's EA again, but I doubt EA will spend over a billion dollars for a game license...

I play on all-star, I play my league, nothing crazy. But the variable shot bar is so annoying and bad. I have had countless barely contested shots that have literally 0 green area, so a 0% chance to make the shot. You should never have a 0% to make any shot, players make tough shots in real life all the time. The PC in this game seems to make some shots that if it was me shooting it would not have any green zone and 0% chance. The free throws, god the free throws, I will make it with the bar not even close to the green then I will max the bar to a would be perfect green and it misses. It makes no sense and I‚Äôm so over it. These are just small part of the larger story that makes this game the worst in history. 

Along with the usual, no changes in graphics, game modes, features, everything is exactly the same. The poor mechanics and gameplay are a result of years and years of not feeling the pressure to change the product. Leaving a perfect example of why there needs to be competition in the marketplace, there shouldn‚Äôt be only one licensed title, it overall becomes bad for the NBA brand. Its like all us hoops fans are being held hostage and I pray to a god that I don‚Äôt believe in that this comes back to bite them in the ass

86hours in while making this review on steam.
200+ hours alloted on different consoles such as the Switch ver and Xbox combined. 
-
I understand why people hated the Franchise itself not just the 2k24. 
"It's just a roster update"
"It's the same game just a different year"
"Nothing new at all"
-
While Yes, I do agree with this. However it's a "simulation" game for a reason. I'd personally compare it to Stardew Valley and other "farming simulators games" as you have one certain goal on this game genre (simulation). Hell, I'd understand if people gave negative reviews with the Nintendo Switch 2k24, its barely unplayable at 30fps.
-
But to play this game in a steam deck and in a PC, In my opinion, is still one of the best experience I had in terms of simulation games. Sure it isn't the best basketball simulator. I actually still think that NBA Live franchise clocks on top, 2k franchise is still a good simulation if you're looking for a  basketball experience. I don't actually think that you have other choices besides this. 
-
Game still gives me the adrenaline at few MyLeague matches, Myteam pulls gives you the pump when pulling a good card. While MyCareer storyline is Lame. Alternatively SHOOOOOORT and rushed. Literally RUSHED, well in fact it doesn't have any storylines at all lol. MyGM is meh, played for like 10 to 15hrs and immediately think that MyLeague still clocks on the game modes. MyPark or Rec or whatever you call it, not really my cup of tea. Never touched it not even once. Only played MyCareer without playing at the Park.
-
Regardless, Game ISN'T perfect. Yes, it doesn't have major changes on every year's releases. But giving you a good simulation that won't let you lose interest (at least for me lol) is definitely a solid buy.

The worst 2k Game of all time and arguably the worst game ever on steam. Inside scoring is completely broken. The badge system is broken. The limitations on the myplayer builds are so bad a 99 rated myplayer isn't actually 99 it's equivalent to a 75 rated player at best. Seriously, check your max attributes versus actual 90-99 rated players in the game. All to just try to get you to spend money on your build. There is no good build, your build isn't the problem, they are hoping you will think your build is bad so you try another build and spend more money. I never spend money I just earn my vc playing the game and it has never been more of a miserable experience than this. Mycareer is once again a mandatory internet connection which is bs It was always a single player mode that you could take online if you wanted to. Now when the servers are down you won't be able to continue playing your guys. I don't even play online. It is ranked as one of the worst and at one point was the worst rated game on steam so my opening statement is in no way hyperbole. This game has truly climb it's way to the pinnacle of the garbage heap. The closest thing I've had to fun on this game is team building in myleague and simulating the seasons to see how good of a team I put together. My long time favorite game mode of Mycareer is completely ruined in every way now.

Not even worth it for the $10 I spent on it. I can't even comment on whether gameplay is good or not because the game constantly crashes and freezes so I probably spent like 20 minutes actually on the court (fwiw it felt pretty good for the limited time I played). Not to mention how goddamn expensive it is to make a build in this game. I don't even care about park/online, I just want to play MyCareer (which has less features than the oldest Xbox 360 games btw) and can't even have an enjoyable experience on that because you are a 60 OVR and every meaningful upgrade costs like 2k VC for a single upgrade, and on HOF with an A teammate grade I got 1k VC. I can't speak on MyLeague but no Eras sucks, adds so much replayability to be able to start from all the way back in the 1980s, so it's probably only worth if you really like the gameplay this year (again can't really comment on that cause I barely got to play lmfao).

Sports games get a lot of hate nowadays, which is why I usually purchase them myself and give them a chance, but I promise you, listen to the reviews. It's genuinely horrible, hopefully 2k25 will be better now that PC is getting current gen, but if the gamemode that separated this game from NBA Live is still locked behind what is essentially a $200 paywall just to play OFFLINE, then I don't have much hope. Anyways, back to 2k16 for now I guess lol.

Where do I even begin with this one...

Man, back in the days, coming from NBA Live from uh.. some other big gaming publisher, I discovered the NBA 2k series back in 2006 and it was...a revelation. Miles ahead already back then in terms of both presentation and gameplay.
I've kept in touch over the years until NBA 2k16. After that, I merely watched the yearly trainwreck unfold on social media when thousands, no millions of people again flocked around the yearly NBA 2k Update.

The core of the game is still there. The animations are mostly good, the gameplay is mostly solid, apart from when it's not. Overall, on the court, you still can't find a better virtual Basketball experience to this day.
Maybe that's part of the problem.
Lack of competition makes things stale. Uninspired. Atriously bad. Oh my god, so bad.

I've always loved the idea of playing my own character and getting a feeling for how an NBA career might feel like. My go-to fantasy was always: Simon Jordan, a nephew of the great His Airness. Same family name, huge burden. He understands the implications and he's not a copy of the original, he's a great player in his own right. No, he grows into one.

This is what I am looking for, by the way, Visual Concepts, if you are reading this. The journey, the growth from a talented rookie with clear weaknesses, into a hall of fame candidate.

What are you giving me here?
The weirdest, pointless, annoying, mood-killing cut-scenes I have ever had to endure in any game. They're so bad, you can hardly even meme on them.
My player, young Mister Jordan is already in some big fancy apartment somewhere, clearly a millionaire. Surrounded by an annoying manager, girlfriend and social media lady.
"That's why your fans hate you probably, lol", my rival Shep tells me. I didn't ask btw. No idea why this douche is my rival at all, why he seems like he is about to stab me on the way to the lockerroom. Or why my player first shrugs it off with a coolness, until my "rival" says: "ha, the sun even shines on a dog's ass sometime!" - and oh boy, suddenly my character gives him a look that should kill him, but sadly doesn't.

What the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• am I watching? Skip.

I play my first game. My player has an average rating of 70. Not great, not terrible. I somehow shoot 70 % from mid-range, but I don't know why. There is very little shot-feedback. Clearly, a step back. Let alone the fact that I am being benched for most of the 4th quarter despite having scored the most points on my team.

After the game, the season is supposed to start! Yay!
Except, no, first, I am being invited to a special club, of which only the best players can be a part of. Clearly, that's me... Mister draftpick number 18! This is where I can satisfy all my shopping needs!
...My dudes, I just want to play Basketball and have a succesful season. What is this? Metabook?
Disgusted, I try to upgrade my first ability with the 850 Virtual Coins I have earned.
There is no real money involved, yet I feel like I just got my lunch money taken from me.

I feel... disillusioned. NBA 2k 23 is a pale shadow of it's former gloryful self. The music, the menus, the lack of meaningful improvements in gameplay, a backstory that could have been done better for 5 $ by some guy/gal from Fiverr in 10 minutes.

I really really wanted to like this game, I really wanted to play some virtual basketball in 2022 (btw after 2k Games made 2k16 literally obsolete and unplayable even offline!) but I just can not stand this piece of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• garbage. For the love of Kobe Bryant please stop buying this garbage game, show the developers that this is not what we want in a game!

Or maybe it is me? Am I so out of touch? No, it's the children who are wrong!

-Jump shot timing seems different for every shot making it impossible to time
-Same reused animations from the last 10 games
-Cannot make wide open shots in MyCareer unless they are green (meter different every shot) *it actually seems like there are varying levels of input lag every shot even in single player offline (running 144fps low latency monitor)
-99 overall MyCareer player feels like an 80 overall role player.
-Lazy game design. Make the gameplay fun idc about true sim because it does not achieve that either
-Even for $10 i feel robbed blind and cannot refund the product so here I am.
-I would be playing 2k22 MyCareer still if they had not shut the servers off or made the MyCareer mode singleplayer only accessible via the servers (yes, I cannot play my singleplayer mode MyCareer at all bc the servers are shut off in 2k22)
-Takes about $150 dollars in real world VC OR playing for months straight to fully level MyPlayer. 
-Battlepass on a $70 game?? Despicable microtransactions. Do not even consider playing online park unless you spend money on your player or play for months on end to level up.
*Overall I would give this game a solid 4/10. Would never consider paying full price for any 2K these days. Coming from a billion dollar franchise it is concerning.

The 2023-24 NBA season ended and the start today option for MyLeague still doesnt work. It hasnt worked since launch. Expansion teams crash the MyLeague mode often. MyLeague pre-made draft classes provided by 2K are incomplete and innacurate as well as player stats and tendencies. Wrong heights and weights for players as well in one draft class provided by 2K Luis Scola and Nene were listed at 6'3 and 6'4 when irl they are 6'9 and 6'11 just to name an example.Kenyon Martin has an A three pointer with a 0 3PT tendency in the game and irl carrer 3PT% of 23% on less then 1 three a game. Embarrasing. Endless amounts of UI bugs and glitches. No eras mode, no next-gen graphics. Online modes completely unplayable because of cheaters and insane latency. If you want to play online you have to completely re-learn the game. Playing actual basketball is not advised either way online because you will probably lose to dudes spamming threes after going left and right for 23 out of the 24 seconds on the shotclock and abusing the latency. MyTeam mode sucks no player is unique and everyone does everything so team strategy is non-existant just put the tallest player you can in every position they all have the same stats anyway Kareem with a 90 three pointer? Why not. MyCareer is the same as always endless grind for no reason just to restart it next year but now with fake overalls. Your "99" OVR player will actually have the stats of about an 85-86 OVR real player if you compare them. Cashgrab game that is cosplaying being a basketball game. If they werent the only ones on the market they would be shut down by now as the quality of the game is insulting to say the least.

The worst 2k Game of all time and arguably the worst game ever on steam. Inside scoring is completely broken. The badge system is broken. Seriously, check your max attributes versus actual 90-99 rated players in the game. All to just try to get you to spend money on your build. This game has truly climb it's way to the pinnacle of the garbage heap. **NBA 2K24: A Slam Dunk of Basketball Gaming Brilliance**

NBA 2K24 continues the legacy of excellence set forth by its predecessors, delivering a basketball simulation experience that's unparalleled in its depth and realism. Developed by Visual Concepts, this installment raises the bar yet again with stunning graphics, immersive gameplay, and a plethora of features that cater to both casual fans and hardcore basketball enthusiasts alike.

**Gameplay and Realism**

From the moment you step onto the virtual court, NBA 2K24 impresses with its attention to detail. Player movements, animations, and physics are meticulously crafted to mirror the intricacies of real basketball. Dribble moves, shooting mechanics, and defensive strategies feel intuitive and responsive, allowing for strategic gameplay that rewards skill and practice. Whether you're executing a perfect pick-and-roll or sinking a buzzer-beating three-pointer, every action feels impactful and true to the sport.

**Modes and Content**

NBA 2K24 offers a wealth of game modes to keep players engaged for hours on end. The MyCareer mode returns with a compelling story-driven experience where you create your own player and navigate their journey from rookie to NBA superstar. The MyTeam mode lets you build and manage your dream team through card packs and player auctions, adding a layer of strategy and collection to the game. Additionally, the revamped MyLeague mode provides deep customization options for those who prefer to manage every aspect of a franchise.

**Presentation and Visuals**

Visually, NBA 2K24 is a feast for the eyes. Player models are incredibly detailed, capturing the likeness and unique characteristics of NBA stars with astonishing accuracy. Arenas are meticulously recreated, complete with dynamic crowds and broadcast-style presentation that enhances the immersion. Whether playing on current-gen or next-gen consoles, the game showcases Visual Concepts' commitment to pushing the boundaries of graphical fidelity in sports gaming.

**Community and Online Play**

The online multiplayer experience in NBA 2K24 is robust and engaging. Compete against friends or players from around the world in head-to-head matches, participate in online leagues, or test your skills in weekly challenges and events. The community aspect of the game is thriving, with active forums, social media integration, and regular updates that keep the gameplay experience fresh and dynamic.

**Critique**

While NBA 2K24 excels in almost every aspect, there's one area where many players, myself included, wish for improvement: in-game prices and microtransactions. The cost of virtual currency and the pricing of in-game items can feel steep at times, making it challenging for players who wish to progress or customize their experience without significant investment. Better deals and more accessible pricing options would undoubtedly enhance the overall player experience and foster a more inclusive community.

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, NBA 2K24 sets a new benchmark for basketball gaming with its unparalleled gameplay, stunning visuals, and extensive content offerings. Whether you're a die-hard NBA fan or simply enjoy immersive sports simulations, this game delivers in spades. While there's room for improvement in the pricing structure, the sheer quality and depth of NBA 2K24 make it a must-have for any gaming library. Lace up your virtual sneakers, hit the court, and experience the thrill of NBA action like never before.

NBA 2K24: A Court of Dreams with My Sunshine LeBron

As an avid fan of basketball and the NBA 2K series, NBA 2K24 delivers an exhilarating experience that brings the intensity of the game right into your living room. The attention to detail is unparalleled, capturing every drop of sweat from the men in this game, every powerful dunk which gets the blood running, and every strategic play that makes basketball so ballin.

Playing as some of the best athletes in the world, the game truly shines when you control the likes of LeBron James, who I fondly call "my sunshine." LeBron's in-game representation is nothing short of spectacular. His movements, his skill, and even his signature style are flawlessly brought to life, making every moment on the court with him feel special.

In conclusion, NBA 2K24 is a triumph for basketball fans. It captures the essence of the sport, celebrates the talent of its athletes, and provides endless hours of entertainment. Whether you're playing with LeBron James or any other superstar, the game offers an authentic and exhilarating experience that is second to none. If you're a fan of basketball, this game is a must-have.

Alright, so I finally got my hands on NBA 2K24, and I have to say, I'm pretty disappointed. Let‚Äôs talk about the major issues: the delay during gameplay and the insane cost of upgrading player stats.

First off, the delays are just ridiculous. Whether I‚Äôm playing online or offline, the game lags and stutters constantly. It messes with player movements, shot timing, and overall responsiveness. It‚Äôs like, come on, how am I supposed to enjoy the game when every move feels off because of the lag? Even when I'm playing offline, where you'd think it would be smooth, it still stutters. It‚Äôs really frustrating, especially when you‚Äôre trying to nail those crucial moments.

Now, let‚Äôs get into the microtransactions. Upgrading player stats in this game is just crazy expensive. Every stat point costs a ton of Virtual Currency (VC), and earning VC through gameplay takes forever. To give you an idea, bumping up a single attribute by a few points can set you back thousands of VC. If you‚Äôre not willing to shell out real money, you‚Äôre stuck grinding for hours and hours just to make a tiny bit of progress. It really feels like a pay-to-win situation, and that‚Äôs super unfair.

On the plus side, the game looks amazing. The graphics are top-notch, with super detailed player models, realistic animations, and the arenas look fantastic. But honestly, the great visuals don‚Äôt make up for the gameplay issues and the aggressive microtransactions.

There are plenty of modes to choose from, like MyCareer, MyTeam, and Play Now. But again, the fun is really dampened by the delays and the fact that you almost have to spend extra money to get anywhere in MyCareer. It‚Äôs a slog if you don‚Äôt.

In conclusion, NBA 2K24 has some serious problems. The lag makes it hard to enjoy the game, and the cost of upgrading player stats is just way too high unless you‚Äôre willing to spend extra cash. The graphics are great and there‚Äôs a lot of content, but that doesn‚Äôt make up for the major drawbacks. If you‚Äôre a huge fan of the series, you might be able to look past these issues, but for most players, it‚Äôs a letdown.

Pros:
- Amazing graphics and realistic animations.
- Lots of game modes and content.

Cons:
- Major delays and lag during gameplay.
- Upgrading player stats is way too expensive.
- Feels like a pay-to-win situation.

Honestly, unless these problems get fixed, it‚Äôs hard to recommend NBA 2K24. It‚Äôs a step back for the series, and it just feels like they‚Äôre prioritizing making money over making a fun game.

NOTE: I am strictly an offline-only player so if you play online, this review may not apply to you
The game is very good, but I got this under the assumption that the NBA Cup/In-Season Tournament would be in the game. Apparently the PS5 has it (after an update in November 2023), but the PC version for some mysterious reason does not have it despite the 100+ GB size of the game.

However, the real PA announcers all being present does lead to a very fun and realistic in-game experience.
The game feels structurally the same since NBA 2K10, the only difference being the rule changes over the years and various presentation & graphical improvements. I must note that if you want to save & quit your game, do it at the inbound pass, otherwise it won't be at the same point.

I may keep it around for when I feel like playing some basketball, but it can't truly be "NBA 2K24" without the NBA Cup, no? That was one of the main reasons for me getting this game. It seems to be a previous 2K with a bit more pizzazz (after some brief research, 2K22?)

For only $10 as a "roster update" of sorts for an offline player, this game can be worth it. But as a full-price game, I can't recommend it at all, considering it doesn't even have the In-Season Tournament. Oh well, maybe next year?

I got this on sale for $9 cause I haven't played 2k in years and I wanted to use updated rosters. First things first, MyCareer Mode. It's the only reason I play 2k at all. I think that as we stopped playing at each other's houses we started shifting towards that mode instead of instant-play style matching. It absolutely sucks in this. You have to be online at all times. You earn barely anything from games themselves and their challenges. You are capped so low that you'll never be able to reach a point of satisfaction with your player, you'll always have to cheese the game instead of playing fun basketball. The timing is so awful. I get excellent quite often and I still think it's ridiculous. It's impossible for me to tell in any clear manner when to release my shot. I've got a pretty good system of looking for a specific shape in my shooting arm before I release, but still. I always enjoyed no shot meters while playing. What is this whole new rpg style map???? Like seriously. what the hell. Waste of time. Annoying to figure out. Mandatory for some progression. The graphics do not justify a brand new game every year. The biggest scam of all time. We could still be playing a version like 2K16 with updated rosters. Hell even just patches and roster updates. And now everything pushes you to spend money on VC. It's pay to play or have no life

Most of the criticism for this game is valid and 100% true. Here is a pros and cons list on 2k24.

Pro:
- Game works great, with some mishaps
- Create a character easy to understand, multiple options for different play styles
- Multiple options for character customization, including different brands for shoes and clothes
- Fun to shoot the ball around and ball out during games
- Fun to play park with friends in 2s or 3s

Cons:
- The game is the last gen version, which does not make sense since the PC version should be the best version in my opinion
- Connection issues in the Park / Neighborhood hurts due to having to re-enter these modes or restart
- Less on-court dialogue due to last gen version
- Less content due to last gen version

Overall:
- This game gets a 6.5 out of 10. If the game was not the last gen port, it would be higher due to the content that was cut from the PC version. The servers could be better, but I do have fun messing around either by myself or with friends.

I am here for WHOEVER is thinking of buying this game. First i would like to say that I have played EVERY Nba 2k since they came out. I have also played basketball for MANY years. Basketball is like a religion to me. For this review I am going to look at it from a PC gaming perspective. 

Is NBA 2K24 Worth Buying? The PC version of NBA 2K24 is NOT next gen, however, there are changes that have been added. It is not (no matter what people may tell u) a copy and paste of last year. Players in the game react differently to being hit in different parts of the body while in mid air, this is new. game play is MUCH smoother and not as glitching as last year when the screen gave u an eye decease when ur player dribbled down the court. Lighting is different and players may point to crowd and say something when hitting a shot is also new. The layout and menu is COMPLETELY different and I mean that in a good way. Now final thoughts. If you are looking for HYPER REALISTIC graphics and A NEW 2K WE HAVE NEVER SEEN BEFORE....than this is not what u want. But if u are looking for the LATEST rosters and some changes in game-play and some fun basketball, then heck yea, go for it. Personally I didn't get the game UNTIL it was on sale for $9.49 and may I say, it was worth it. So give it a try!

So the gameplay itself is really fun and doesn't have many issues, but, there are so many connection problems. In the open world part of MyCareer when you try to teleport somewhere half of the time it just doesn't work, it loads for a bit and then just puts you right back to where you were. A lot of the time when just trying to open MyCareer it loses connection and I half to reconnect and it sometimes even logs me out (it keeps my login information so its not a big deal but still). So there could be a whole lot done to make this game better in those areas, but like I said I think that the gameplay part is really fun and doesn't have many issues.

NBA 2K24 is an exceptional entry in the long-running basketball simulation series, offering both die-hard fans and newcomers an immersive and engaging experience. The game boasts stunning graphics that bring every player and arena to life, creating a highly realistic atmosphere that mirrors the excitement of real NBA games. NBA 2K24 introduces improved gameplay mechanics, making dribbling, shooting, and defense feel more fluid and responsive. The addition of new animations and refined player movements adds to the authenticity, ensuring that each match is a dynamic and thrilling experience. Furthermore, the game features a rich soundtrack and commentary, enhancing the overall immersion and making each game feel like a live broadcast.

One of the standout features of NBA 2K24 is its diverse range of game modes, catering to various playstyles and preferences. Whether you enjoy building your dream team in MyTEAM, guiding your custom player through a career in MyCAREER, or competing online with friends, there's something for everyone. The MyCAREER mode, in particular, offers a deeply engaging storyline that allows players to experience the journey of an NBA superstar, complete with personal and professional challenges. Additionally, the online multiplayer modes provide endless replay value, enabling players to test their skills against others from around the world. With its comprehensive features, enhanced gameplay, and unmatched realism, NBA 2K24 is a must-have for any basketball enthusiast looking for a top-tier sports gaming experience.

I won't waste words. This series feels like being alone in an elderly home watching your father gradually pass from dementia. My first 2k game was 2k11 in high school. It was a dope game and I enjoyed the series for years. I felt like I could always have fun in 2k.

I took a break a couple years ago. This is my first time getting back into. Every bad system has been retained and has been meticulously engineered to be worse. All of the good systems have been dropped. Games feel bad in every mode. Difficulty is no longer rewarding, it's simply a handicap. Microtransactions are rampant, and it takes 3x the amount of time to max a character relative to my experience with 2k11 all those years ago. At my current rate, it will take three full seasons to max my character without microtransactions. I'm not sure what I would max for. The online community feels empty and bitter. It feels like nobody is having fun.

If you enjoy NBA basketball and want to feel unbearably sad, pick up NBA 2k24. I wish I would have left my negative review and collected my refund while the window was open, but it's important to see that few great things last forever. An incredible heartfelt product iterated upon time-after-time will eventually become just a product. If you want to play good basketball, buy a pair of shoes and hit your local park up. The old guy with anger issues who won't stop hand checking you still appreciates you more than 2k.

NBA 2K24: A Steep Shot with Glittering Rewards

NBA 2K24, the latest iteration of the popular basketball simulation game, delivers an undeniably polished and exciting on-court experience. Yet, much like a dazzling alley-oop overshadowed by an overzealous traveling call, the game's brilliance is marred by intrusive monetization strategies.

For basketball purists, NBA 2K24 is a dream. The "ProPLAY" technology seamlessly translates real-life NBA footage into in-game animations, resulting in smoother player movement and a heightened sense of authenticity. Whether mimicking Giannis Antetokounmpo's powerful drives or Stephen Curry's lightning-quick releases, the gameplay feels incredibly responsive.

Beyond technical prowess, the variety of game modes keeps players engaged. MyCAREER, the story-driven mode where you build your own basketball superstar, boasts a revamped narrative and a vibrant city hub to explore. MyTEAM, the card-collecting mode, allows you to curate your dream roster of current and historic players.

However, the path to competitive glory in these modes feels paved with microtransactions.  The virtual currency, VC, is essential for upgrading your MyCAREER player's abilities and acquiring top players in MyTEAM. Earning enough VC through gameplay can be a tedious grind, incentivizing players to purchase it with real money. This nickel-and-diming approach casts a shadow over the otherwise immersive experience.

Ultimately, NBA 2K24 is a game of two halves. On the court, it's a slam dunk, delivering the most realistic and engaging basketball simulation to date.  Off the court, however, the aggressive monetization tactics leave a bitter aftertaste.  For casual fans, the core gameplay might be enough. But for serious players, the pay-to-win elements may feel like a foul call.

Recommendation: Purchase game off G2A.com. For die-hard basketball fans, the gameplay improvements may outweigh the monetization issues.

So, I'm going to add my voice to all the negative reviews here. I did the math, and it would take 3 seasons at Pro level, or 50 dollars worth of VC to get to just an 86 OVR Player. Playing at a 60 OVR player is a slog on so many levels, and it's really designed to bleed money out of your wallet. The game may as well say "Buy the game, then insert 50 dollars to actually have fun." Also, coming from 2k21, things are missing. There's no story, each character you create is the same face, so you can no longer customize based on role. It's a shittier game even being newer. And 2k21 was not a particularly spectacular game. The greed is way too much, it's not worth it in any discount. I thought picking it up for 10 bucks would be worth it, but no. It's just "Insert money to have fun: The Game."

There‚Äôs no sense in paying full price for what is basicaly the same game every year. The biggest disappointment is that for the third year in a row, 2K didnt port the new-gen version of NBA 2K to PC, even tho most PCs are as if not more powerful than a PS5.

Even at the highest settings, the game looks bad, and you‚Äôre stuck with the old-gen version, which means the entire game experience from menus to graphics to features looks worse than the PS5 version. 

If you still decide to purchase, get ready to spend more. Playing MyCareer mode is nearly impossible without spending out over $100 to upgrade your player to a decent OVR. The single-player mode in MyCareer is incredibly difficult to win unless you buy VC to improve your player and be able to compete. The opposite team can barely score 4 points in a quarter, but as soon as you're substituted out for 2 minutes, they become prime Tracey McGrady, and score 13 points in 33 seconds (which is absurd). And by the time you're back in the game, you'll be down by 20 points.

Worst 2k/basketball game by far. I would rather play NBA Live as my only option over whatever the hell this is supposed to be. MyCareer has never been worse, the shooting mechanic continues to get worse year after year. Everything is hidden behind a paywall, the overall gameplay is uninspired and recycled from all of the previous games. At this point their studio needs to shut down. To say they are tone deaf and out of touch with their player base is a gross disservice to how bad things actually are. $10 and I still would never recommend this game to anyone. This is the worst game to ever exist. It is full of micro-transaction and latency issues. The game is nearly unplayable at times, from the latency to the necessity for VC to even have a viable character. You will need to spend a lot of time or money to actually have some small enjoyment with the game. There is so much lag with the meter and visual cues that it is very difficult to hit shots as a low OVR; in some instances, it is impossible. Also, the game is in last gen and has been for the last 3-4 years or so and may not even be next year. It is actually laughable how much 2K disrespects the PC audience. You are missing out on many key features, from an actual career mode, updated graphics, and an old builder, plus some other BS they are not giving you. I don't even think this game is worth $10, to be honest.

Unless this game is on a huge sale, it's not worth getting. This years 2K forces players to be hyper specialized with their characters. The game also forces you to start as a 60 overall which feels awful in career mode with no opportunities to make a large amount of VC to at least get your character to a decent level. It definitely feels like their primary goal this year was to force players to buy VC just so their player feels functional. 2K has the same issue as Madden, they've had the license for too long with no significant competition resulting in lackadaisical game design and function. Got this game for $8, would never pay full price for a 2K game until they can prove they can make a good game again.

Terrible. Last nba game I played was nba2k20 and that was pretty enjoyable. Played the crap out of that. Decided to pick this one up to play mycareer again since they've switched off mycareer in 2k20. 
It's impressive how the same game 4 years later, has the same graphics, same animations, same overall mechanics, same loading screen cutscenes with utter time wasting bs that you can't skip or mute. I gota apply for a job at 2k, they must spend all day smoking weed or something because they sure as shit aren't improving this game. 
Despite it being the same recycled game, the directional passing in 2k24 sucks ass, 3 pointers are impossible while every AI opponent is an expert 3 point shooter, movement is sluggish af even for an nba2k game and the delay responding to the input is atrocious. But what does it for me is the rng in the release mechanic. In 2k20 I could shoot 10x and use the animation to get consistent results. Here, you can get 10x "excellent" in a row, and the very next training, same exact practice exercise, using the same exact timing, and you get "early", "slightly late", "slightly early". It's all over the place. It's almost like the game does it on purpose and just adds rng to your release window to get you frustrated and make you to buy vc to max your stats asap. Welcome to 2k, the new EA :)

Stephen Curry is a 36-year old American professional basketball player who plays at the Point Guard or Shooting Guard position for the Golden State Warriors in the NBA. He is 6 feet 2 inches (188cm) tall, weighs 185 pounds (83kg), and has a wingspan of 6 feet 4 inches (193cm).

Steph played college basketball at Davidson College. He joined the Davidson Wildcats for the 2006-2007 season and played through the 2008-2009 season. During his time at Davidson, he became known for his exceptional shooting ability and scoring prowess. He quickly gained national attention for his long-range shooting and his ability to score in various ways. He declared for the NBA Draft after three years in college. He was selected as the 7th overall pick by the Golden State Warriors in the 2009 NBA Draft.

For the 2023-2024 NBA season, Stephen Curry's salary is $51,915,615.

I been a 2k gamer since I was a kid in the early 2000s. Since after 2k14, NBA 2k has been an absolute cash grab. My first time purchasing and playing a 2k on pc as I usually play it on whatever the current console is, and it's literally the last Gen version of 2k24 (not the ps5 or Series X version) but they ask for retail price and have the pricey big VC versions for you to buy. The on court game play itself isn't bad other than every player moving like they have cemente boots on, and creating space with dribbling is a chore as every defender feels like MJ or Scottie Pippen locked in in a closeout game for a championship. Because this isn't the current Gen version, PC players don't get the widely popular MyEras mode where you can basically play a franchise mode in any major era like Magic & Bird, Jordan or even early 2000s era, and re-write those eras in your own way throughout past years up until now. As a 2k gamer since way before they ever had a create your own player career mode and parks and all that VC cash grab non sense, I played franchise mode heavy, so a mode like MyEras would've been awesome to play. Guess I'll just have to buy this on sale for ps5 to play that mode. Not a bad game in general, just really slow moving game play, last Gen version so it's missing key modes and it feels like a cash grab.. I mainly play it for MyLeague franchise mode and to me that's all that's really good about this game.
Sincerely, fuck you assholes. Fuck you.

There's a lot bad with the PC version of this game. It continuing to be the last gen version is a bummer, and their attempts at shutting down the mod scene is an even bigger bummer. I would love to be able to enjoy the Next Gen MyNBA Eras mode with the addition of cyberfaces for guys like Charles Barkley, Reggie Miller, etc who aren't in the game. That being said, if you're willing to go out of your way to un-update your game every update, there can still be some fun to be had using the mod tools that are out there. I'm sure 2K hates that I can do it, but I have a celeb team on my save like they had on 2K13 where I can play with Bad Bunny and Jake from State Farm and Ronnie2K, and it's a small thing that I get a lot of enjoyment out of, and for me it was worth the like 20 bucks I spent when it was on sale. That being said, I wouldn't really recommend buying it for full price. It really only taps into a very specific niche at this point, and you're much better off buying it on console.

I paid 9.59 for this. I ONLY PLAY FRANCHISE mode aka myleague OFFLINE. I'd try myplayer if the off ball movement wasn't so terrible and if it wasn't so painfully restrictive as far as attribute limits is concerned.

Cons: There are too many locked in forced animations that make aspects of the game too unrealistic. 

Finishing at the rim with any sort of contact is way nerfed and inconsistent.

Passing is unrealistically slow. I'm talking there's a 1-2.5 second delay from the time you press pass to when the ball is actually passed. Often times the intended recipient moves as you're passing it but not in a way that's good or helpful. They'll move into other defenders so that what ends up happening is you pass the ball DIRECTLY into a defenders hands. 

Moving without the ball is almost non-existent. Watch or play a real life game, Do people mostly stand around watching the ball handler like 2015 Rockets? No, there is constant movement, screens being set, Shooters running to an open spot behind the 3 point line when the ball handler drives and the defense collapses. Bigs drifting out of the paint to unclog the lane. Tons and tons more. This stuff rarely happens in the game. There's mostly people standing watching the guy with the ball.

After getting an offensive rebound you get trapped in this state where your player doesn't move normally. For example, let's say you grab an offensive rebound and want to immediately turn and sprint the the corner, Well the game locks you into a state where even if you jam turbo and flick the left stick to all the way it doesn't register. The player will take 2-3 short choppy steps first THEN go back to normal and actually sprint.

Offensive rebounding on the CPU is ridiculously OP. Every game without fail will have someone on the opposing team grabbing 8 offensive rebounds.  I had to lower it from 50 to 40.

Long rebounds are almost non-existent. Mostly every miss doesn't leave the paint.

The announcers are lackluster. At this point i'd rather they use AI for more dynamic reactions and commentary.

The courts are too shiny any reflective. I know it looks aesthetically pleasing but personally I find it distracting and I'd like the option to turn it off. 

Pros: When the game is clicking, ball is moving, crowd is hyped...It's fun. They did a good job with the crowd reactions

Star players perform on the court like star players. Their impact in the game is clear and noticeable. 

Conclusion: If I had paid pull price for this i'd be disappointed but for 9.59 it's  worth it for me. The game itself is fun, rewarding and challenging. I've had LeBron cook me, Curry torch me and it was awesome. Scouting the draft class, signing free agents, tracking award leaders all that stuff is still fun and interesting to me. I've been playing since the first 2k on Dreamcast and still find basketball beautiful. It's unfortunate that 2k went from a yearly must have purchase to  only buying every 2 years and on a 70 percent or more discount. I didn't play live but I sure as hell appreciated them pushing 2k to innovate. I drafted Wemby and every game I gotta hear REJECTED BY WEMBANYAMAAA!!!  7 times.
